title: 110_hr4308
content: The Act may be cited as the "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007". It establishes the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by charitable donations or program proceeds. The Fund can be used for advertising and administrative expenses, with limits on expenditures set by appropriations Acts. The NASA Innovation Fund can be used for prize money awarded under section 314 of the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury can invest the Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The obligations can be acquired on original issue or by purchase at market price, and sold at market price. Interest and proceeds are credited to the Fund. The interest and proceeds from the sale or redemption of obligations in the Fund are credited to and form part of the Fund. NASA INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise the Administrator on program implementation. The committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator. Members serve staggered three-year terms. The Advisory Committee members serve staggered terms to ensure continuity of administration. Vacancies are filled by the Administrator for the remainder of the term. Members cannot serve for more than 6 years and are not compensated but reimbursed for expenses. The Committee must meet at least 4 times a year as called by the Administrator. The Advisory Committee meets at least 4 times a year, with the Administrator and Chief of Strategic Communications of NASA or their designees present to provide guidance. Additional meetings may be called by the Administrator. SEC. 4. INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. A sponsor is a person approved to participate in the program. The Administrator will select a logo for sponsors based on Advisory Committee recommendations. To apply as a sponsor, a person must submit an application to the Administrator. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program requires applicants to submit proposals with details on the amount to be contributed, a description of the promotional program using the Partnership Logo, and plans to promote education and opportunities in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Each person approved as a sponsor must enter into a Sponsorship Agreement. The Sponsorship Agreement for approved applicants requires providing a specified amount and allows the use of the Partnership Logo in promotional programs. Restrictions include no logos on spacecraft, astronaut endorsements, agency-wide endorsements, or in-kind contributions. The Administrator establishes restrictions on contributions, including no in-kind contributions, minimum contribution levels, and other inappropriate features. Procedures are in place to protect proprietary information, and NASA is encouraged to participate in promotional programs. Enforcement measures are in place for unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo. The Administrator enforces restrictions on contributions and unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo through civil actions, including injunctions and civil penalties of $100,000 per violation. Additionally, the Administrator may report to Congress annually on these enforcement actions. The Administrator must report to Congress annually on all actions taken by NASA, including receipts, expenditures, and evaluation of the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. The Advisory Committee must also report on its actions. The Committee consults with directors of NASA Centers to improve the program. NASA's Langley Research Center, Marshall Space Flight Center, and Stennis Space Center are key facilities that play a crucial role in the agency's operations. The National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 is amended to include the NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007. Definitions in the Act include terms like Administrator, NASA, Partnership Logo, and Promotional program.
